jparsec.time

Class AstroDate

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.time.AstroDate
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class AstroDate
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    A class to store date/time values with a precision of one second or better. Support to retrieve the Julian day number is given for the Gregorian and Julian calendars.

    Selectable dates are not limited in years, but there are some invalid dates (non existent) in the civil calendar, between October 5, 1582 and October 14, 1582. They can be instantiated if desired, but it is not possible to work with them without the corresponding exception.

    Note: This library uses GregorianCalendar for dates equal or after October, 15, 1582. For dates before that the library uses the Julian Calendar. The Before Christ era (B.C.) is automatically selected by setting a zero or negative year as the year in the GregorianCalendar instance. Year 0 corresponds to year 1 B.C. (year 0 does not exist by itself). When using an instance of AstroDate occurs the same. The only difference is that here month '1' is January. In GregorianCalendar January is month '0'. To avoid confusion it is recommended to use always AstroDate as the instance for dates, as well as the provided symbolic constants for the months.

    In the constructors the year is entered considering that year 0 does not exist, so year -1 is 1 B.C. When retrieving the year the value returned follows the same rule. But internally, in the instance, the year is hold in the astronomical way, where 1 B.C. is year 0.

    Date/time can be specified either in the Gregorian Calendar or the Julian Calendar for any instant using DateTimeOps.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain), M. Huss
    See Also:
    GregorianCalendar, DateTimeOps, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate()
        Default constructor for current instant. Precision is 1 ms.

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(int year,
         int month,
         int day,
         int hour,
         int min,
         double sec)
        Explicit day, month, year, hour, minute, and second constructor.
        Parameters:
        year - Year. Should not be zero.
        month - Month of the year (1..12).
        day - Day of the month (1...31).
        hour - Hour of the day (0...23).
        min - Minute of the hour (0...59).
        sec - Second of the minute (0...59).

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(int year,
         int month,
         int day)
        Year, month, day constructor (time defaults to 00:00:00 = midnight).
        Parameters:
        year - Year. Should not be zero.
        month - Month of the year (1..12).
        day - Day of the month (1...31).

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(java.lang.String cdsDate)
          throws JPARSECException
        Creates an instance from a date expressed in a common way, like the standarized format Fri, 29 Jul 2011 23:30:44 +0200, a simple way like 2001 Jan 1 or Feb 17 2005 10:00:00, MJD50000.125, and so on.

        The date is parsed by means of the cds package.

        Parameters:
        cdsDate - Date.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(int year,
         int month,
         double day)
        Day (with decimals), Month, Year constructor (time defaults to 00:00:00 = midnight).
        Parameters:
        year - Year.
        month - Month of the year (1..12).
        day - Day of the month (1...31) and fraction of days.

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(java.util.GregorianCalendar cal)
        Deprecated. Dates cannot be represented in a GregorianCalendar with a precision better than 1 ms.
        Convert a GregorianCalendar instance to an AstroDate.
        Parameters:
        cal - An instance of java.util.GregorianCalendar.

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(long t)
          throws JPARSECException
        Constructor for a date given as a long value, representing the number of milliseconds elapsed from 1970, January 1, at 0 h.
        Parameters:

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(double jd)
          throws JPARSECException
        Julian Day constructor of a Gregorian AstroDate.
        Parameters:
        jd - Julian day number.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the Julian day is invalid.

      • AstroDate

        public AstroDate(java.math.BigDecimal jd)
          throws JPARSECException
        Julian Day constructor of a Gregorian AstroDate.
        Parameters:
        jd - Julian day number as a big decimal. Internal precision of this class (the seconds from midnight are stored as a double) is around 0.5 nanoseconds or better (precision will be close to the femptosecond close to midnight, which is second 0).
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the Julian day is invalid.

    • Method Detail

      • jd

        public static double jd(AstroDate ad,
        boolean julian)
                 throws JPARSECException
        Convert an AstroDate to a Julian Day. See Meeus, Astronomical Algorithms, chapter 7.
        Parameters:
        ad - The date to convert.
        julian - true = Julian calendar, else Gregorian.
        Returns:
        The Julian Day that corresponds to the specified AstroDate.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the Julian day is invalid.

      • jd

        public static double jd(AstroDate ad)
                 throws JPARSECException
        Convert an AstroDate to a Julian Day.

        Assumes the AstroDate is specified using the Gregorian calendar if the AstroDate is October, 15, 1582 or later. The Julian calendar will be used for dates before October, 5, 1582. Intermediate dates will throw an error.

        Parameters:
        ad - The date to convert.
        Returns:
        The Julian Day that corresponds to the specified AstroDate.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the Julian day is invalid.

         throws JPARSECException

        Parameters:

        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the resulting date is invalid.

        public double jd(boolean julian)
          throws JPARSECException
        Convert this instance of AstroDate to a Julian Day.
        Parameters:
        julian - true = Julian calendar, else Gregorian.
        Returns:
        The Julian Day that corresponds to this AstroDate instance.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the Julian day is invalid.

        public boolean isInvalid()
        Check if the AstroDate instance contains an invalid date. A date is invalid between October 5, 1582 and October 14, 1582.
        Returns:
        true if the date is invalid, false otherwise.

      • getHour

        public int getHour()
        Get the Hour.
        This function truncates, and does not round up to nearest hour. For example, this function will return '1' at all times from 01:00:00 to 01:59:59 inclusive.
        Returns:
        The hour of the day for this instance of AstroDate, not rounded.

      • getMinute

        public int getMinute()
        Get the minute.
        This function truncates, and does not round up to nearest minute. For example, this function will return 20 at all times from 1:20:00 to 1:20:59 inclusive.
        Returns:
        The minute of the hour for this instance of AstroDate, not rounded.

      • getSeconds

        public double getSeconds()
        Returns the seconds (elapsed from last minute) for this instance.
        Returns:
        Seconds.

      • getRoundedHour

        public int getRoundedHour()
        Get the rounded hour.
        Returns the hour of the day rounded to nearest hour. For example, this function will return '1' at times 01:00:00 to 01:29:59, and '2' at times 01:30:00 to 01:59:59.
        Returns:
        The hour of the day for this instance of AstroDate, rounded to the nearest hour.

      • getRoundedMinute

        public int getRoundedMinute()
        Get the rounded minute.
        Returns the minute of the hour for this instance of AstroDate, rounded to nearest minute. For example, this function will return 20 at times 1:20:00 to 1:20:29, and 21 at times 1:20:30 to 1:20:59.
        Returns:
        The minute of the hour for this instance of AstroDate, rounded to the nearest minute.

      • getRoundedSecond

        public int getRoundedSecond()
        Get the rounded second.
        Returns:
        The second of the day for this instance of AstroDate, rounded to the nearest second.

      • toMinString

        public java.lang.String toMinString()
                             throws JPARSECException
        Convert this AstroDate instance to a String, formatted to the minute. This function rounds the exact time to the nearest minute.

        The format of the returned string is YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm.

        Returns:
        A formatted date/time String.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the date is invalid.

      • toStringDate

        public java.lang.String toStringDate(boolean showTime)
                              throws JPARSECException
        Convert this AstroDate instance to a String, formatted like 'September, 5, 2012 [, 00:00]'.
        Parameters:
        showTime - true to show the time.
        Returns:
        A formatted date/time String.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the calendar month is invalid.

      • toMinStringTZ

        public java.lang.String toMinStringTZ()
                               throws JPARSECException
        Convert this AstroDate instance to a String formatted to the minute, with Time Zone indicator.
        Rounds the time to the nearest minute.

        The format of the returned string is YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm TZ, where TZ is a locale-specific timezone name (e.g., "EST").

        Returns:
        A formatted date/time String.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - For an invalid date.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Convert this AstroDate instance to a String.

        The format of the returned string is YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss.

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A formatted date/time String.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString(int nsec)
                          throws JPARSECException
        Convert this AstroDate instance to a String.

        The format of the returned string is YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss[.ssss].

        Parameters:
        nsec - Number of decimal places in the seconds field. Set to -1 to show the time up to the rounded minute.
        Returns:
        A formatted date/time String.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - For an invalid date.

      • toStandarizedString

                                     throws JPARSECException
        Returns current date in a standard format. For instance, Fri, 29 Jul 2011 23:30:44 +0200
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        The formatted date.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • toStringTZ

        public java.lang.String toStringTZ()
        Convert this AstroDate instance to a String, with Time Zone indicator.

        The format of the returned string is YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss TZ, where TZ is a locale-specific timezone name (e.g., "EST").

        Returns:
        A formatted date/time String.
